What is a PEP?

 

A PEP is someone who holds a prominent public position or function in a government body or an international organisation, including:

 

•

Head of State or head of a country or government

•

government minister or senior politician

•

senior government official

•

judge of the High Court, the Federal Court, or a Supreme Court of a State or Territory or equivalent senior judge in a foreign country or international organisation

•

governor of a central bank or any other position that has comparable influence to the Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia

•

senior foreign representative, ambassador, or high commissioner

•

high-ranking member of the armed forces

•

board chair, chief executive, or chief financial officer of, or any other position with comparable influence

 

A PEP also includes a close family member of the above people, and a close associate who has an ownership arrangement with the above people. Politically exposed people may be from countries with widely-known problems of bribery, corruption and financial irregularity, or those with lax anti- money laundering standards.

 

Your organisation's AML/CTF program must include systems and controls to determine whether a customer or beneficial owner of a customer is a politically exposed person (PEP). You must determine the beneficial owner before providing a designated service to the customer, or as soon as practicable after you have provided the service.
